TO: Members of the HAEB Research Ctanittee®
From: Sam L0 Becker
Bate: April 24, 1958
Subject: Meeting of the KARR Research Committee at the (Kilo State
Institute, May 12-15«
First of all, X am sorry to say that I will not be able to attend
the Institute o There are so many items of business which demand the
attention of the Research Qm®it tee, however, that it seems to me
Imperative that those mashers who are in attendance meet in order to
discuss the issues involved. Bhfortunately, there is no money avail¬
able to pay the expenses of cosmittee members to attend the Institute
However 3 If enough members are already attending to make a meeting
possible and if it is impossible for this meeting to be held during
the formal period of the Institute so that meshers must come a day
early or stay a day after the Institute ends, hotel and meals can be
payed for this one day. As I understand it, funds are not even avail¬
able at this time for the expenses of Board members in general, who
will also be meeting. 1 would like to know if you are planning to
attend and if you believe that it will be possible for you to meet
with the committee during the regular period of the Institute or
whether you believe it will be necessary to remain and meet the day
following the Institute.
We do not yet know how much money there will be for research
activities next year. The extent of such activities depends on the
success of Faulu, Skornia, and the others who are working on this
problem. We know that we will have $2,000.00 for sure — possibly
far more. I believe that w© need to plan for any eventuality. There¬
fore, I think that these are subjects which need discussion and your
ideas:
1. If we have just $2,000.00, how can this be spent most profitably?
a) Should we continue the Grants-In-aid? If so,
(1) Should we redefine their purpose?
(2) Should we be more specific in the announcement about the
sorts of expenses to be paid? The kind of research in which
we are interested? The kind of research in which we are not
interested? For example, you might think it desirable in a
particular two or three year period to try to encourage a
series of studies on the ©pinion leaders and educational
broadcasting. (Washington as you recall, is doing one similar
to this.) This might be a partial answer to our need for a
better measure of educational broadcasting intact.
